snippet: California's budget crisis deepened today when the Bank of America, the nation's second-largest bank and the biggest in the state, said that on Aug. 5 it would stop accepting the i.o.u.'s the state has been issuing employees and other creditors wh...
lead_paragraph: California's budget crisis deepened today when the Bank of America, the nation's second-largest bank and the biggest in the state, said that on Aug. 5 it would stop accepting the i.o.u.'s the state has been issuing employees and other creditors while Gov. Pete Wilson and legislators fight over the $11 billion deficit. Later, Wells Fargo Bank, the state's second-largest bank, reiterated its position that it would stop accepting the i.o.u.'s, or "registered warrants," dated after July 31.

headline.main: 2d Big Bank Sets I.O.U. Deadline For California
